name: King Charles III England Coast Path: Maldon to Salcott

ai.summary: A strenuous coastal traverse along the England Coast Path from Maldon to Salcott, covering 84.8 km. The route combines estuary shorelines, tidal flats, and low-lying coastal terrain with strong exposure to wind and tides, demanding solid navigation, endurance, and careful planning.
ai.terrain_summary: Predominantly coastal path with a mix of compact trails, mud, mudflats at low tides, boardwalks, and occasional gravel or dirt tracks. Expect open exposure, shifting sands, and water effects from estuaries; navigation may require following signs along a remote coastline.
ai.safety_notes: Hard, long-distance coastal hike. Plan for multiple days or long daily distances. Check tide times and weather; some sections can be inaccessible at high tide. Wear sturdy waterproof boots with good grip; consider gaiters for mud. Carry enough water and energy-rich snacks; have a plan for shelter in bad weather. Bring a map, compass or offline GPS and a fully charged phone. Tell someone your route and expected times. Be prepared for sudden weather changes and sea spray; apply sunscreen and wear layers. Watch for muddy or slippery surfaces and close gates behind you when encountered.
recommended_gear: Moisture-wicking base layers and additional insulating layer
Gloves (optional but useful in cold coastal winds)
Water bottle or hydration system (2–3 L)
High-energy snacks and some electrolyte options
Map and compass (or offline GPS) and a fully charged phone
Headlamp or flashlight with extra batteries
First aid kit and emergency whistle
Trekking poles (optional for stability on uneven ground)
Emergency bivy or space blanket (for multi-day trips)
Extra socks and lightweight dry bag for valuables
ai.best_seasons: Spring to autumn (roughly March–October) are most favorable; winter conditions can be harsh with strong winds and shorter daylight.
